name.text: 7.3.2.1 Laplace expansion along the top row, minors

questiontext.text:
Laplace expansion along the top row

This is a technique which can be used to evaluate determinants of any order. In principle, this method can use any row or any column as its starting point. We quote one example: using the top row.

Consider \(\Delta=\begin{vmatrix} 4 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \end{vmatrix}\).

First we introduce the idea of a minor. Each element in this array of numbers has an associated number called its minor, calculated by removing the column and row in which the element lies and taking the determinant of the remainder. For example consider entry \(a_{23}=3\). To calculate the minor associated with this entry, we strike out the second row and the third column:


which leaves \(\begin{vmatrix} 4 & 1 \\ 3 & 1 \end{vmatrix} = 4 - 3 = 1.\) For the entry \(a_{31}=3\) we strike out the third row and first column:


which leaves \(\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 3 \end{vmatrix} = 3 - 2 = 1.\)
